@graph.description: The Ultimate Guide to Summer Landscape Photography - 15 Tips To create breathtaking photographs, essential to master techniques and understand the fundamentals.
@graph.articleBody: The Ultimate Guide to Summer Landscape Photography The Ultimate Guide to Summer Landscape Photography - 15 Tips Summer is a magical season for photography, especially when capturing the beauty of landscapes. The warm sun, vibrant colours, and lush greenery create the perfect backdrop for stunning images. Whether you're an experienced photographer or just starting, this comprehensive guide will equip you with the knowledge and tips to maximise your summer landscape photography adventures. As the seasons change, so does the landscape, offering a plethora of photographic opportunities throughout the year. Summer and autumn, in particular, present distinct characteristics and colours that can elevate your landscape photographs. The Magic of Summer Landscape Photography Summer Landscape photography is a powerful art form that allows us to capture the essence and grandeur of the natural world. It invites us to immerse ourselves in the beauty of our surroundings and preserve fleeting moments for eternity. Through skilful composition, thoughtful use of light, and a keen eye for detail, landscape photographers can transport viewers to breathtaking vistas and evoke a deep sense of connection with nature. Mastering the Techniques: Tips for Stunning Summer Landscape Photography To create breathtaking landscape photographs, it is essential to master various techniques and understand the fundamentals of composition, lighting, and exposure. Let's delve into some essential tips that will elevate your landscape photography skills and help you capture images that truly encapsulate the beauty of nature. View fullsize summer landscape photography tips Essential Tips for Summer Landscape Photography  The Importance of Location: Finding the Perfect Spot Choosing the right location is crucial in landscape photography. It sets the stage for your composition and determines the mood and atmosphere of your photographs. Whether you prefer the rugged beauty of mountains, the tranquility of lakes, or the enchantment of forests, there are endless possibilities to explore. Researching potential locations, visiting them at different times of the day, and understanding their unique features will help you create compelling and captivating images.  Harnessing the Power of Light: Golden Hour and Blue Hour Light is the soul of photography, and landscape photography can transform an ordinary scene into something extraordinary. The golden hour, which occurs during the first hour after sunrise and the last hour before sunset, bathes the landscape in a warm, soft light that adds a touch of magic to your photographs. The long shadows, golden tones, and gentle glow create a captivating atmosphere that brings out the textures and colours of the landscape. Similarly, the blue hour, which happens before sunrise and after sunset, offers a serene, ethereal light that casts a beautiful blue hue and adds a sense of tranquillity to your images. Embrace these magical hours to capture the true essence of the landscape.  Understanding Composition: Creating a Visual Story Composition is the backbone of any great photograph, and landscape photography is no exception. It is the art of arranging the elements within your frame to create a visually pleasing and balanced image. By following the rule of thirds, leading lines, and incorporating foreground interest, you can guide the viewer's eye through the photograph and create a sense of depth and dimension. Experiment with different compositions and perspectives to find the one that best conveys your vision and tells a captivating visual story.  Capturing Dynamic Skies The sky is often a captivating element in landscape photography, adding drama and depth to your images. Pay attention to the weather conditions and look for opportunities to capture dynamic skies filled with clouds, vibrant sunsets, or dramatic storm formations. Use graduated neutral density filters to balance the exposure between the sky and the landscape, ensuring a well-exposed image.  Exploring Unique Perspectives To create truly memorable landscape photographs, challenge yourself to find unique perspectives and viewpoints. Instead of settling for the typical tourist shots, venture off the beaten path and discover hidden gems that offer fresh and unexpected angles. Climb hills, explore valleys, or wade through streams to capture the landscape from a new and exciting vantage point.  Harnessing the Power of Foreground Interest Foreground interest adds depth and visual impact to your landscape images, drawing the viewer's attention into the scene. Look for interesting elements such as rocks, flowers, or leading lines that can serve as a compelling foreground. Experiment with different aperture settings to achieve the desired depth of field, ensuring that both the foreground and the background are in sharp focus.  Working with Filters: Enhancing the Landscape Filters are valuable tools in landscape photography, allowing you to control and manipulate the light entering your camera. A polarizing filter, for example, can reduce glare and enhance colours, particularly in skies and bodies of water. Neutral density filters help you achieve longer exposure times, creating a sense of movement in elements such as flowing water or clouds. Graduated neutral density filters can balance the exposure between the sky and the foreground, ensuring that both areas are correctly exposed, you can also use exposure bracketing AEB. Experimenting with different filters will expand your creative possibilities and enable you to capture the landscape uniquely and captivatingly.  Mastering Depth of Field: Creating Dimension Depth of field is a powerful tool in landscape photography, enabling you to control the sharpness and blur within your image. A wide depth of field, achieved by using a small aperture, ensures that both the foreground and background are in focus, allowing the viewer to explore the scene in detail. On the other hand, a shallow depth of field, accomplished with a wide aperture, can isolate a specific subject or element, creating a sense of depth and emphasizing its importance within the frame. Understanding how to manipulate depth of field will add dimension and visual interest to your landscape.  Exploring Minimalism: Simplifying the Scene In landscape photography, sometimes less is more. Embracing minimalism allows you to simplify your compositions, focusing on key elements and creating a sense of calm and tranquillity within your images. Look for scenes with a strong focal point or a single element that catches your eye. It could be a lone tree, a rock formation, or a single flower in a vast field. By simplifying the scene and eliminating any distractions, you can draw attention to the beauty and significance of the chosen element. Pay attention to negative space and use it to create a sense of balance and harmony within your composition. Experiment with different angles, focal lengths, and depth of field to create minimalist compositions that evoke a sense of serenity and allow the viewer to appreciate the beauty of the landscape in its purest form.  Exploring Cultural and Historical Landscapes: Telling Stories Through Photography Landscape photography is not limited to capturing natural scenery; it can also be a powerful tool for documenting and preserving cultural and historical landscapes. These landscapes are imbued with stories, traditions, and a sense of heritage that can be conveyed through your photographs. Whether it's an ancient castle perched on a hilltop, a centuries-old tree with a rich history, or a traditional village nestled in the countryside, cultural and historical landscapes offer a wealth of photographic opportunities. Take the time to research the significance and history of the location you are photographing, as this knowledge will inform your compositions and help you capture the essence of the place. Look for unique architectural details, cultural events, or local traditions that can add depth and context to your images.  Exploring the Details While landscapes are often associated with vast vistas and sweeping panoramas, macro photography allows you to explore the natural world's intricate details and hidden beauty. Summer is a season teeming with life, from delicate flowers and buzzing insects to intricate textures and patterns that can be captured up close. Invest in a macro lens or extension tubes to get closer to your subjects and reveal the hidden world that exists within them. Look for interesting textures, colourful flowers, or tiny creatures that can be transformed into stunning works of art through macro photography. Pay attention to lighting, using diffusers or reflectors to soften harsh shadows and highlight the intricate details of your subjects. Experiment with different compositions, angles, and depths of field to create visually captivating images that showcase the beauty and complexity of the natural world on a small scale.  Post-Processing: Enhancing Your Images Post-processing is integral to landscape photography, allowing you to fine-tune and enhance your images to match your artistic vision. Use editing software to adjust exposure, contrast, saturation, and sharpness, bringing out the details and colours of the landscape. However, it is important to maintain a balance and avoid over-processing, as it can result in unnatural-looking images. Experiment with different editing techniques and find a style that complements your vision while staying true to the essence of the landscape.  Inspiring Your Creativity: Drawing Inspiration from Others In landscape photography, inspiration can be found in the works of other photographers who have captured the beauty of nature in their own unique way. Explore the portfolios of renowned landscape photographers, study their compositions, lighting techniques, and use of colour, and let their work ignite your own creativity. Additionally, immerse yourself in nature, observe its patterns, colours, and textures, and let it guide you in creating your own visual masterpieces.  Unleashing Your Inner Artist Landscape photography is a journey of self-expression, creativity, and connection with the natural world. Through your lens, you have the power to capture the essence of the landscape, evoke emotions, and inspire others to appreciate and protect our planet. Join me on my summer and autumn landscape photography workshops, where we will explore the wonders of nature and sharpen our photography skills. Remember, the beauty of the landscape is ever-changing, and each moment presents a new opportunity to capture its magic. Embrace the art of landscape photography, unleash your inner artist, and let your photographs tell the story of the world around us.  Nurturing Patience and Perseverance Landscape photography often requires patience and perseverance. Nature can be unpredictable, and the perfect shot may require waiting for the ideal lighting conditions or weather patterns. Embrace the process and allow yourself to slow down, immersing yourself in the surroundings. Take the time to observe and connect with nature; the rewards will be reflected in your photographs. Conclusion: Continuous Learning and Growth - Summer Landscape Photography Photography is a lifelong journey of learning and growth. Stay inspired by studying the work of renowned landscape photographers, attending Summer Landscape Photography workshops and seminars, and continuously pushing the boundaries of your creativity. Experiment with different techniques, equipment, and genres to broaden your skillset and develop your unique interpretations. As summer unfolds before us, it brings with it a world of photographic opportunities and endless beauty waiting to be captured. Through the art of landscape photography, we can preserve the fleeting moments, the vibrant colours, and the timeless allure of nature. By mastering the techniques and embracing Summer Landscape Photography unique perspectives, we can create images that evoke emotions, tell stories, and inspire others. So, join me on my summer landscape photography workshops as we embark on this journey together. Let us explore the golden hour light, capture the power of silhouettes, and unlock the secrets of composition. Let us embrace the art of long exposure, minimalist compositions, and the drama of stormy skies. Together, let us celebrate the beauty of cultural and historical landscapes and dive into the intricate details of macro photography. With your camera in hand and the spirit of adventure in your heart, let us chase the light and capture the essence of summer through the lens of our cameras. @graph.articleBody: Beginners Photography Basics-How to improve your photography Photography Basics - How to improve your photography10 Tips to take beginners to the next level of becoming a better photographer Photography is a powerful art form that allows us to capture and preserve special moments. Whether you're a beginner or have some experience, there's always room for improvement in your photography skills. By understanding the fundamentals of Photography Basics and implementing some essential techniques, you can enhance your images and create stunning photographs that truly stand out. This short guide will explore the common elements of photography basics and provide practical tips and insights to help beginners unlock their creative potential.Table of Contents - Photography Basics  Know Your Camera and Equipment  Master the Fundamentals of Exposure  Composition Techniques for Captivating Images  Understanding Light and Its Effects  Capturing Emotion and Telling a Story  Exploring Different Perspectives and Angles  Editing and Post-processing for Stunning Results  Continuous Learning and Workshop Experiences  Building a Portfolio and Showcasing Your Work  Investing in Professional Tuition for Growth View fullsize photography basics To begin your journey towards mastering photography, you must have a solid understanding of your camera and equipment. Review the manual and familiarise yourself with your camera's different functions, settings, and capabilities. Knowing how to adjust the aperture, shutter speed, ISO, and other settings will give you greater control over your images. In addition to your camera, invest in essential accessories such as lenses, tripods, and filters. Each piece of equipment serves a specific purpose and can significantly enhance your photography. Experiment with different lenses to capture various perspectives and effects. A tripod will help you stabilise your camera for sharp, long-exposure shots, while filters can add drama, greater exposure control, and creativity to your images. Understanding exposure is fundamental to creating well-exposed and visually appealing photographs. Exposure refers to the amount of light that reaches the camera sensor, and it is determined by three key elements: aperture, shutter speed, and ISO. The aperture controls the amount of light entering the camera through the lens. A wide aperture (low f-number) allows more light and creates a shallow depth of field, perfect for isolating subjects. On the other hand, a narrow aperture (high f-number) reduces the amount of light and increases the depth of field, which is ideal for showing lots of details. The shutter speed determines the duration of time that the camera's sensor is exposed to light. A fast shutter speed freezes motion and is excellent for capturing action shots, while a slow shutter speed creates motion blur and is perfect for long-exposure photography. ISO measures the sensitivity of the camera sensor to light. A low ISO setting (e.g., 100) produces sharp images with minimal noise, while a high ISO setting (e.g., 1600 or higher) is helpful in low-light conditions to reduce exposure time but may introduce grain or noise to the image. Composition is the arrangement of visual elements within a photograph. It is a crucial aspect of photography that can make or break an image. By applying composition techniques, you can create visually appealing and impactful photographs. The rule of thirds is a popular composition technique that divides the frame into a grid of nine equal parts using two vertical and two horizontal lines. You create a more balanced and dynamic composition by placing your main subject along these lines or at their intersections. Leading lines are another powerful composition tool. These lines guide the viewer's eye through the image, creating depth and directing attention to the main subject. Look for natural or man-made lines such as roads, rivers, or buildings to incorporate into your compositions. Symmetry and patterns can also add visual interest to your photographs. Find symmetrical subjects or repetitive patterns in your environment and use them as the focal point of your composition. Experiment with different angles and perspectives to create unique and captivating images. Light is the essence of photography. It shapes and defines your subjects, sets the mood, and adds depth and dimension to your images. Understanding how light behaves and how to manipulate it will significantly enhance your photography skills. Natural light provides soft and flattering illumination for your subjects. Pay attention to the quality and direction of light throughout the day. The golden hours, shortly after sunrise and before sunset, offer warm and diffused light that adds a beautiful glow to your photographs. Avoid shooting in harsh midday sunlight, which can cast unflattering shadows and create high contrast, unless of course this is what you are working with, then consider mono (B&W) as an option. Alternatively, you can experiment with artificial lighting sources like flash or continuous lights. These tools give you more control over the intensity, direction, and colour of light. Play with different lighting setups to create dramatic portraits, still-life compositions, or even light painting effects. Photography is not just about capturing moments but also about conveying emotions and telling stories. Consider the emotions you want to evoke in your viewers and find creative ways to capture them. To capture genuine and authentic emotions, photograph people in their natural state. Candid shots often result in more compelling and emotionally charged images. Engage with your subjects and create a comfortable environment that allows them to express themselves naturally. In addition to emotions, your photographs can also tell stories. Think about the narrative you want to convey and use elements such as composition, lighting, and subject placement to enhance the storytelling aspect of your images. A well-executed storytelling photograph can engage viewers and leave a lasting impression. Exploring different perspectives and angles can add a unique and creative touch to your photographs. Instead of shooting from eye level, challenge yourself to think outside the box and experiment with unconventional viewpoints. Getting down low and shooting from a worm's-eye view can make your subjects appear larger than life and create a sense of grandeur. On the other hand, shooting from a bird's-eye view can provide a fresh and unique perspective, especially when photographing landscapes or crowded scenes. Consider the foreground and background elements in your compositions. Including interesting foreground elements can add depth and lead the viewer's eye into the frame. Experiment with different angles and heights to find your subject's most visually appealing composition. Editing and post-processing are crucial in enhancing your photographs and bringing out their full potential. With the advancements in technology, numerous software options are available to help you edit and refine your images. Start by organising your photos and selecting the best ones for editing. Use software like Adobe Lightroom or Photoshop to adjust the exposure, contrast, colour balance, and other parameters to achieve the desired look and feel. Experiment with different editing techniques, but remember to maintain a natural and realistic appearance. Post-processing also allows you to correct any imperfections or distractions in your images. Remove dust spots, unwanted objects, or distractions using the spot healing brush or clone stamp tool. Don't be afraid to experiment with creative editing techniques, such as black and white conversion or adding selective lighting effects, to further enhance your images. Photography is a never-ending journey of learning and growth. Even experienced photographers constantly seek new knowledge and techniques to improve their craft. Engaging in continuous learning opportunities like workshops and classes can significantly enhance your photography skills. Investing in professional tuition and gaining workshop experiences provide you with structured learning methods and personalised development. Workshops offer a hands-on approach, allowing you to practice new techniques and receive immediate feedback from experienced instructors. They also provide valuable networking opportunities, allowing you to connect with other photographers and learn from their experiences. Additionally, workshops often occur in inspiring locations, providing unique subject matter and beautiful backdrops for your photographs. By immersing yourself in these learning experiences, you'll improve your technical skills and gain a deeper understanding of the art and the ability to express your unique vision. As you progress on your photography journey, building a portfolio to showcase your best work is essential. A portfolio is a collection of your strongest images representing your unique style and vision as a photographer. Select your best photographs across different genres and create a cohesive and visually appealing portfolio. Consider the sequencing and flow of your images to create a narrative or tell a story. You can create a physical portfolio to present in person or build an online portfolio using platforms like Instagram or other dedicated photo sites. Regularly update your portfolio with new and improved work to reflect your growth and evolution as a photographer. Sharing your portfolio with others, whether through online platforms or in-person exhibitions, allows you to receive feedback, gain exposure, and potentially attract clients or opportunities for collaboration. While self-learning and experimentation are valuable, investing in professional tuition can accelerate your growth as a photographer. Professional instructors can provide guidance, personalized feedback, and expert knowledge to help you overcome challenges and reach new heights in your photography journey. Consider enrolling in photography courses or workshops led by experienced photographers specialising in your interest areas. These courses can cover various topics such as technical skills, composition, lighting, editing, and more. By learning from professionals, you'll gain insights and techniques that are difficult to learn on your own. Professional tuition also offers a structured learning environment, allowing you to progress logically and organised. It provides a platform for continuous improvement and gives you access to resources, assignments, and critiques that will push you to expand your skills and creativity. Conclusion - Photography Basics Mastering the photography basics is a transformative journey that allows you to unleash your creative potential. You can elevate your photography skills by understanding your camera and equipment, mastering exposure, applying composition techniques, exploring different perspectives, and continuously learning and experimenting. Remember, photography is a lifelong learning process, and with dedication and practice, you can create stunning images that truly captivate and inspire. Invest in professional tuition, gain workshop experiences, and build a portfolio to showcase your progress and share your unique vision with the world. Embrace the art of photography and embark on a journey of self-expression and creativity. @graph.articleBody: Creative Photo Editing with DXO NIK Collection 6 - Creative editing plays a crucial role in transforming ordinary images into extraordinary works of art in photography. And when it comes to creative editing, the DXO NIK Collection is a name that stands out. The NIK Collection has been a photographer's favourite for years with its powerful plugins and innovative tools. And now, with the release of DXO NIK Collection 6, there are even more exciting features and enhancements to explore.The Evolution of NIK Collection 6 The NIK Collection has come a long way since its launch in the '90s. Over the years, it has changed ownership several times, but its reputation for its black-and-white and colour film looks has remained legendary. Today, DXO is the proud owner of the NIK Collection, and they continue to improve and enhance the software with each new version. Introducing NIK Collection 6 NIK Collection 6 by DXO is the latest version of this powerful photo editing suite. Packed with new features and improvements, it offers photographers even more control and flexibility in their editing process. Whether you're a professional photographer or an amateur enthusiast, NIK Collection 6 has something to offer. Enhanced U PointTM Tool One of the standout features of NIK Collection 6 is the enhanced U PointTM tool. This innovative tool has been upgraded with new Control Lines, allowing you to combine the power of Control Points with the flexibility of linear gradients. With Control Lines, you can create graduated filter effects with precision and ease. Whilst this is an excellent addition to the plugin, I tend to make this type of adjustment in Lightroom before using NIK or refine it after using NIK. In addition to Control Lines, the U PointTM tool now includes Color Selectivity filters. These filters allow you to tie the impact of Control Points and Control Lines to the brightness and colour of specific parts of your image. This level of control gives you unparalleled precision in your local adjustments. Inverted and Diffused Adjustments NIK Collection 6 introduces the ability to invert and diffuse your Control Points and Control Lines. This means you can apply adjustments to specific areas of your image and then easily reverse or soften those adjustments as needed. This level of flexibility allows you to experiment and fine-tune your edits confidently. Improved Workflow Features In addition to the enhancements to the U PointTM tool, NIK Collection 6 also brings a range of improvements to the overall workflow. One of the notable improvements is the ability to save and rename your local adjustments. This means you can keep track of all your fine edits and easily access them whenever you need further adjustments. Another helpful feature is choosing where you want the adjustment sliders to appear. You can keep them in the sidebar for a clean interface or have them on top of your image for easy adjustments. NIK Collection 6 also allows you to save your local adjustments as part of your presets, making it even easier to apply quick changes to your images. Smart Objects and Presets NIK Collection 6 introduces new features that make your editing process even more non-destructive. You can now turn your edits into Smart Objects, allowing you to make adjustments without permanently altering your original image. This gives you the freedom to experiment and make changes without fearing losing any critical details. Presets are another powerful tool in NIK Collection 6. You can now search for presets by name, making it easier to find your favourite edits. With just a few clicks, you can apply your saved presets to your images, saving you time and ensuring consistency in your edits. Updated and Rebuilt Plugins NIK Collection 6 brings updates and rebuilds to several of its plugins. Nik Color Efex, one of the most popular plugins in the collection, now includes a brand-new Hue/Saturation/Luminance tool. This tool gives you deeper and more accurate control over the colour and tone of your images.  Nik Dfine, another essential plugin in the collection, has received a complete visual overhaul. The new interface aligns it with the other plugins, creating a more refined editing experience. Additionally, you can save denoising profiles and easily return to them in just a few clicks. Nik Perspective, known for its powerful geometric adjustments, now features the impressive ReShape tool. This tool allows you to warp and shape local areas of your image, giving you total precision in correcting geometry and creating artistic effects. The Nik Sharpener plugin will receive a rebuild and interface overhaul in a future update, while Nik HDR Efex will get a fresh new interface in an upcoming release. These updates and improvements ensure that the NIK Collection remains at the forefront of photo editing technology. DXO NIK Collection 6 - System Requirements and Pricing NIK Collection 6 is available for both Windows and macOS platforms. The software is compatible with popular photo editing applications such as Adobe Photoshop, Lightroom Classic, and Affinity Photo. It can also be used as a standalone application. The pricing for NIK Collection 6 is 135 for new customers while existing owners of NIK Collection 4 or 5 can upgrade at a special price of 69. The software can be installed on up to three computers and does not require a subscription. Conclusion - DXO NIK Collection 6 With its enhanced U PointTM tool, improved workflow features, and updated plugins, NIK Collection 6 by DXO is a must-have for photographers seeking creative editing capabilities. Whether you're a professional or an enthusiast, NIK Collection 6 offers the tools and flexibility you need to bring your images to life. So why wait? Upgrade to NIK Collection 6 and take your creative editing to new heights. Unleash your artistic vision and transform your photographs into true works of art. With NIK Collection 6, the possibilities are endless. @graph.articleBody: How to develop your skills | Become a better photographer Become a better photographerHow to develop your skills as a photographer - become a better photographer You have acquired the basics and are now looking to develop your skills as a photographer further. It doesnt take rocket science to turn your everyday snaps into inspiring pieces of art, worthy of comment; using my knowledge, I have written this step-by-step guide on how to grow your photography skills: Tools of the trade are essential. Its not necessary to have the biggest and best camera on the market  or even to possess a digital camera. Film cameras are just as relevant and useful today as they were prior to the digital age. The most important thing is to get suitable equipment for your individual requirements and expertise. Have your camera at the ready Carry your camera around with you, whenever possible. You might find yourself suddenly looking at a stunning scene: but if your camera isnt with you, you miss out on what potentially may have been your best shot to date. However, it is rare for these opportunities to just present themselves to you. You need to get out into the world and look for them. Day or night, dry or wet, warm or cold  all conditions are perfect for the right photo, at the right time. Inspiration is everywhere There are so many colours, textures and patterns around you just waiting to be discovered and incorporated into original and stunning photographs. I offer a range of workshops where you can learn so much in the beautiful British outdoors. Hone your skills and create enchanting photos for people to admire and enjoy. You can even customise your tuition to suit your specific needs with my pick and mix tuition packages. Simplicity is beauty Avoid trying to focus on too much at once. If there is something that doesnt add anything to the composition of the shot, then it doesnt need to be included. Keep it simple and youll get a much more focused shot. Share your work An important part of your development is sharing your photos with the world and receiving feedback. Listening to constructive criticism from other artists is one of the best ways to improve the way you work. Theyll understand the impact you would like your photos to have; they may see ways as to how you can tailor your skills to achieve those goals. Full constructive feedback is given throughout all my courses, together with ongoing support, taking you further along the creative journey of the craft of photography. Know your equipment - become a better photographer Knowing all about the extras on high-tech digital cameras isnt essential, but it is useful in getting the most out of your shots. Dont be afraid to experiment with your equipment as well as researching the range of tools available to you. Feel comfortable with how you work - become a better photographer Do you feel at your best out in the elements of nature or surrounded by busy town life? Whatever your preference, inspiration is all around us; your potential is limitless in a world that is so diverse and full of opportunity. What inspires you when you are out and about, looking for subjects on which to focus? Id love to receive comments, and everyone has their own perspective on life. I take great pleasure in teaching and developing photography skills. Whatever level you wish to work at or the type of camera that interests you, Im happy to provide insights, tips and personalised training. @graph.alternativeHeadline: Camera Bags - Review of Manfrotto Backpack Advanced Fast III | Alan Ranger Photography
@graph.description: Best Camera Bags - An honest review of the Manfrotto Backpack - Advanced Fast III - And what to look for in your perfect camera bag to deal with most situations.
@graph.articleBody: this article, we will explore the features and benefits of this innovative camera bag and discuss how to choose the right bag for your needs. Before we get into the details, I want to admit to being a camera bag junky - In twenty years of being an active photographer, I think I have massed the equivalent of a bag a year for my needs. Weirdly my needs havent changed that much over time. The quantity of gear I take out on a workshop or my own wanderings is pretty standard for the most part. However, bags age faster than me with exposure to all weather conditions and bundled in and out of the car, on my back, or the ground. Sometimes I want to travel with one lens and maybe a couple of accessories, filters, spare battery, water bottle, lunch box etc. other times, I want to take two or even three lenses and more. So, over the years, I have leaned towards having two types of camera bags. Though I still constantly question whether there is something in between that does it all. Ive not found it yet but have come close to it with my current main bag. Which I am more than happy with to date.  Small but big enough to carry a camera body and one lens, plus a small amount of accessories and a water bottle. The day pack. Large but still convenient for weight, comfort, space and versatility. i.e. I can include clothing (hat, gloves, jacket), a flask and a water bottle, filters, and other accessories. The review of this bag falls into the first category of the all-day, one-day type, where you need a range of options for multiple lenses, filters and other equipment and clothing. Therefore a 15ltr - 25ltr capacity is usually adequate. This bag falls in the middle of this range at 18.5ltr volume. How to Choose the Right Camera Bag for You When selecting a camera bag, it's essential to consider your specific needs and requirements. Here are some key factors to consider when choosing the right bag for you: Key Camera Bag Requirements Protection of gear: Ensure the bag offers adequate padding and protection for your valuable equipment. Comfort and weight: Look for a bag with an ergonomic design and padded straps to minimize strain during transport. Versatility and space: Consider the gear you need to carry and ensure the bag offers enough compartments and access points to accommodate your needs. Overall size: If you travel frequently, ensure the bag meets carry-on luggage standards for your preferred airline or has so much space that you overpack it and damage your back. Quality of materials: Opt for a bag made from high-quality, durable materials to ensure longevity and performance. I should probably add a sixth point - Cost but when you consider the cost of your gear running into the thousands very quickly these days, I dont think spending 10% of that on a decent bag to protect it and use it as you want to is something to be compromised. Review of the Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack IIIthe FeaturesProtection of Gear One of the most critical aspects of a camera bag is its protection of your valuable photography equipment. Manfrotto has considered this with the Advanced Fast Backpack III, featuring their new M-Guard Protection System. This system uses high-density EVA foam to provide exceptional shock absorption and a slim profile for added space efficiency. M-Guard Protection System The M-Guard Protection System in the Advanced Fast Backpack III ensures that your gear remains safe and secure during transport. The customized folding patterns of the foam padding allow for maximum versatility and protection while maximizing the use of space within the bag. Comfort and Weight Another essential factor when selecting a camera bag is the comfort it provides, especially during long hours of shooting or traveling. The Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III is designed with padded shoulder straps and a comfortable back panel to ensure that carrying your gear is a breeze. Ergonomic Design The ergonomic design of the backpack helps distribute weight evenly, reducing the strain on your shoulders and back. This is particularly important for landscape photographers who often have to hike long distances with their equipment. Versatility and Space The Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III is designed to be extremely versatile, with multiple access points and compartments to accommodate a wide range of gear. The bag can hold a full-frame mirrorless camera with an attached 70-200 mm f/4 lens, three additional lenses, a flash, and a 15-inch laptop. Dual Side Access and Quick Top Access The backpack features dual side access to the main gear compartment, as well as quick top access for additional space. This allows you to easily retrieve your equipment without having to completely open the bag. The top compartment can be used for personal items or a second camera body, depending on your needs. Overall Size The overall size of the camera bag is crucial for photographers who need to travel frequently or carry their gear over long distances. The Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III is designed to meet the standard for carry-on luggage, allowing you to bring it on board most flights without any issues. Cabin Luggage Compatibility Due to ever-changing restrictions, it's essential to check with your airline before departure. However, the Advanced Fast Backpack III is designed to fit within most carry-on luggage limitations, making it a convenient choice for photographers on the go. Manfrotto Backpack - Quality of Materials The materials used in a camera bag play a significant role in its durability and performance. The Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III is made from high-quality, water-repellant fabric, ensuring your gear stays dry even in adverse weather conditions. Manfrotto Backpack - Water Repellent Fabric and Rain Cover The external fabric of the backpack is treated to repel water, and the bag also comes with an included rain cover for additional protection. This ensures that your equipment remains safe and dry, even in the most challenging environments. Manfrotto Backpack - Additional Features The Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III boasts several additional features that make it an excellent choice for photographers of all levels. Manfrotto Backpack - External Tripod Connections The bag comes with proper connections to attach your tripod externally, ensuring you can bring along all the necessary equipment for your shoot. Manfrotto Backpack - Interchangeable Dividers The backpack includes modular and easy-to-use dividers that allow you to custom-fit the interior of the bag to accommodate your specific gear. This ensures that everything remains secure and organized during transport. Manfrotto Backpack - Laptop Compartment The Advanced Fast Backpack III features a dedicated, padded compartment for a 15-inch laptop, ensuring your computer stays safe during transport. Manfrotto Backpack - Tablet Compartment In addition to the laptop compartment, the bag also includes a dedicated compartment for a tablet, providing even more versatility for photographers who need to stay connected on the go. Manfrotto Backpack - Trolley Connection For easy transportation, the backpack features a designated strap connector that slides over any standard trolley or luggage handle. This makes navigating airports and other busy environments much more manageable. Testing in the flesh I approached the review of this bag with the parameters of whether it would provide what is needed for a one-day day trip or equivalent. My criteria for that would be: Camera body and two or three lenses Filters (Kase Revolution) NDs and Polariser. A rain jacket Lunch Box & snacks Two Flasks - of water and coffee Spare battery and a small number of other accessories I packed the Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III accordingly Its worth saying up-front that this is an 18.5ltr capacity bag, so its fair to say that you can pack a lot of gear into something similar to most laptop/work backpacks. However, I struggled to get everything needed into such a small space without compromising on ease of access and protection. Lets walk through the negatives and positives. Negatives - Manfrotto Backpack Access & Opening - I wouldnt say I like the front opening access to the camera section - the butterfly design means accessing anything in that area exposes everything to the elements, wind, rain and dust. If your bag were lying on an uneven surface, there would undoubtedly be a risk of items rolling out. Why all bags are not clamshell openings so the back of the pack that goes onto to your back is kept dry and clean is a mystery to me. Width - with only 27cm internal width, my mirrorless body with a mount converter and 70-200mm lens was butted up tight to both sides of the bag. I tried switching the configuration of the dividers but couldnt find a convenient arrangement where everything in that section was secure and protected sufficiently. Space - whilst I could squeeze in my mirrorless body with a lens and two additional lenses, this made the side pockets redundant - I tried to fit a water bottle into the side pocket. Still, the pocket lacked expandable space, so it was impossible to use for a flask or water bottle to either side or both sides. Top Space - Its minimal, and you can about get away with a small lunch box and cagoule-type jacket, but forget trying to pack any padded/thicker clothing in too. Positives - Manfrotto Backpack Size - The bag is compact and meets carry-on requirements so if you want to carry a limited amount of gear and accessories, you should be able to get away with using this to carry your gear. Materials - if you dont overpack it, the bag should give you adequate protection with its sturdy internal dividers and side padding. Cost - Its within the budget of many beginners and may work well enough as their first all-rounder bag. Summary - Manfrotto Backpack While the Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III offers some promising features, such as versatile access points, a dedicated laptop compartment, and water repellant fabric, it may not be the ideal choice for all photographers. The limited space for additional items and the front-opening design could prove to be inconvenient for those who require a more adaptable and secure camera bag. Photography Shop With over twenty years of experience and numerous camera bags tested, it is essential to prioritize the right size, quality, versatility, and accessibility when choosing a camera bag. The Manfrotto Advanced Fast Backpack III may serve some photographers well in the interim, but it may not be the perfect solution for various trips and shooting scenarios. Overall size: 4/5 - It meets carry-on requirements, and with a single body and one additional lens plus a small number of accessories, it meets the requirements  Quality of materials: 3/5 - Internal dividers are rigid, and external surfaces are okay but wont tolerate a downpour (though a rain cover is included) or general grime and dirt.Cost - for a 100 bag it isnt terrible but in my view isnt fantastic either - Overall Score - 3/5 photography-tips, recommended-productsAlan Ranger31 May 2023news, reviews LinkedIn0 Pinterest0

@graph.articleBody: This guide, Photography Concepts for Beginners, will delve into the three basic components that every beginner photographer should know. By mastering these concepts, you can take your photography skills to the next level and capture stunning images that truly resonate with your audience. Whether you're interested in landscape photography, portraiture, or street photography, these concepts will serve as a solid foundation for your photographic journey. This article assumes you have already acquired the knowledge and understanding of exposure (Aperture, Shutter, ISO) and have now embarked on the journey to creating better pictures. Photography Concepts for Beginners Photography Concepts for BeginnersUnderstanding the Three Main Elements of Photography : The Photo Photography is a blend of art and science, and understanding its basic components is essential for creating impactful images. As a beginner, it's crucial to familiarise yourself with the three main elements that make up a photograph: subject, light, and composition. Let's explore each of these components in detail.  Subject: The Heart of Your Photograph The subject is the main focus of your photograph. It's what catches your eye and draws you into the image. When describing a photo, the subject is often the first thing we mention. It could be a person, an object, or a scene. A powerful photograph captures the essence of the subject and presents it in a visually compelling way. To portray your subject effectively, consider how you want to present it. Do you want to isolate it with a shallow depth of field, or do you want everything in focus? Will your photograph be sharp and detailed, or more artistic and blurred? These technical decisions are creative choices that allow you to showcase your subject in the best possible light.  Light: Painting with Illumination Light is the lifeblood of photography. It determines the mood, atmosphere, and visual impact of your images. Understanding how to manipulate light is crucial for creating stunning photographs. Different qualities of light evoke different emotions and can transform an ordinary scene into something extraordinary. Consider the quality, direction, and color of light when composing your shot. The quality of light refers to its hardness or softness. Hard light creates strong shadows and sharp edges, while soft light produces gentle transitions. The direction of light influences the depth and dimensionality of your subject. Experiment with lighting from different angles to achieve the desired effect. Lastly, the color of light can dramatically alter the atmosphere of your photograph. From warm golden hues to cool blue tones, understanding how to work with different lighting conditions will greatly enhance your images.  Composition: Crafting a Visual Story Composition is the arrangement of elements within your photograph. It is the art of visual storytelling and plays a crucial role in creating impactful images. By considering the placement, balance, and framing of your subjects, you can guide the viewer's eye and convey your intended message. There are various techniques and guidelines that can help you compose your photographs effectively. The rule of thirds, for example, divides the frame into nine equal parts and suggests placing points of interest along the lines or at their intersections. Leading lines can draw the viewer's gaze into the image, while negative space can create a sense of balance and simplicity. Experiment with different compositions to find what works best for your subject and message. Learning Photography Concepts for Beginners is merely the start of your journey - putting those concepts into practise is a key element if you want to progress: Next we discuss five ways to practise the photography concepts for beginners with this short but invaluable guide. Five Ways to Practise Photography Concepts for BeginnersThe Importance of Problem-Solving in Photography As a beginner photographer, it's essential to develop a problem-solving mindset. Every photoshoot presents its challenges, and learning from your mistakes is crucial for growth. When reviewing your images, take the time to analyze the unsuccessful shots and understand why they didn't meet your expectations. Was it a focus issue, depth of field, or camera shake? By critically assessing your work, you can identify areas for improvement and make more informed decisions in future shoots. Remember, photography is not about mindlessly capturing hundreds of frames and hoping for a good shot. It's about being intentional, creative, and disciplined in your approach. Embrace the freedom to experiment while adhering to the principles and techniques that yield the best results. By doing so, you'll sharpen your skills and develop a unique photographic style. Developing Your Photographic Vision While mastering the technical aspects of photography is important, it's equally crucial to develop your own artistic vision. What story do you want to tell through your photographs? What emotions do you want to evoke in your viewers? Take the time to explore different genres, study the work of renowned photographers, and experiment with various subjects and styles. This process of self-discovery will help you find your unique voice in the world of photography. The Power of Personal Projects Engaging in personal projects is an excellent way to refine your skills and explore your photographic vision. Choose a specific theme or concept that resonates with you and challenge yourself to create a series of images around it. This focused approach will not only deepen your technical abilities but also allow you to develop a cohesive body of work that showcases your personal style. Learning from the Experts While self-guided learning is valuable, enrolling in photography classes or workshops can accelerate your growth as a photographer. These educational experiences provide structured learning environments, expert guidance, and opportunities for constructive feedback. Whether it's through online courses, local workshops, or mentorship programs, investing in your education will undoubtedly enhance your understanding of photography concepts and techniques. Embracing the Journey Photography is a lifelong journey of discovery, growth, and self-expression. It's a medium that allows you to capture moments, tell stories, and share your unique perspective with the world. By understanding the fundamental concepts of subject, light, and composition, and by cultivating problem-solving skills and personal vision, you'll unlock your creative potential and create photographs that truly resonate with others. Remember, photography is not just about technical proficiency; it's about capturing the essence of a moment and evoking emotions in your viewers. Embrace the joy of learning, explore new horizons, and never stop honing your craft. With dedication, practice, and a thirst for knowledge, you can become the photographer you aspire to be. So grab your camera, step out into the world, and let your creativity soar! Our expert instructors will guide you through the fundamentals, advanced techniques, and creative approaches that will elevate your skills to new heights and take you beyond the Photography Concepts for Beginners. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced photographer looking to refine your craft, our classes offer a supportive and inspiring environment for growth. @graph.headline: 5 Stages To Improve Your Photography | A Professional Guide
@graph.alternativeHeadline: 5 Stages To Improve Your Photography | A Professional Guide | Alan Ranger Photography
@graph.description: The photographic workflow versus the learning workflow - Identify which stage you need to work on to improve your photography results step by step with guide.
@graph.articleBody: 5 Stages To Improve Your Photography | A Professional Guide My ApproachIs To Improve Your Photography Over twenty years of being a landscape/outdoor photographer and turning my passion into a professional status and a business over ten years ago, I have led thousands of outdoor workshops and classes for clients of all abilities, gear, interests, backgrounds, ages and needs. Throughout this period I have developed many techniques, explanations and events to improve your photography I started my teaching ethos on the understanding that "Pictures are the expression of the photographer; they reflect perception and individuality, portraying a journey through life." Therefore, there are not necessarily rights and wrongs in photography; there is only the ability for each individual to bring their own creative and beautiful vision into the images they make for the purpose required. It does not mean that certain aspects of the execution, focusing, exposure, composition and so on can be ignored, they are essential elements of an image, but they are not the reason for making the image. Photography is a medium to record and express moments, ideals, connections, and interpretations of what we find beautiful, intriguing or important. Based on these principles, I have created a flexible approach to everyone and use a straightforward methodology to help each person get the most out of every interaction with me as their tutor. The Photographic Workflow: To improve your photography The five linear stages of creating a photograph. see | design | shoot | enhance | share.  See - The ability to observe and develop your creative eye. Design - The ability to disclose only the vital and compose. Shoot - The ability to create the best digital negative. Enhance - The ability to edit the image to realise its potential. Share - The ability to share images for enjoyment/outcomes. The Photographic Process 5 Stages To Improve Your Photography Based on the five stages of the photographic process, I teach people through explanations, cues, demonstrations and suggestions throughout each step. I won't instruct clients and what to shoot but help them on how to shoot. More often than not, clients want to master their use of the camera (shoot) first before improving their ability to observe (see), compose (design) and edit (enhance). This is the learning workflow where the stages are rearranged to give learning and development to where it is most wanted (needed is another debate). It is a continuous improvement cycle where we all seek to improve our abilities at any stage to bring more satisfaction and enjoyment to our photography. The Photographic Learning Workflow: To improve your photography shoot| design| enhance | share | see. Camera - Shoot - Learn camera settings and functions and when and how to use them. Composition - Design - Understand how images are composed and why. Editing - Enhance - Learn to use editing software to make critical photo enhancements. Feedback - Share - Feedback on your images and affirmation to progress further. Creativity - See - Expand your creativity through experience, practice, and collaboration. The Photographic Learning workflow 5 Ways To Improve Your Photography See Your capacity to observe, identify, study and create comes through practice and critical thinking at the moment but also after the moment in reflection. Giving your subject full attention requires a mindset and giving yourself time to get into that zone. Often referred to as mindfulness, whatever you call this connection to your topic and environment, its an essential part of improving what and how you photograph anything. My outdoor landscape location workshops are a perfect way to experience new places, meet like-minded people and stimulate your ability to observe and see more. Workshops are carefully planned to suit all levels of experience, and 1-2-1 tuition is provided accordingly. Each location is optimised for timing and interest but not pressured into being a honey-pot bus tour to get the classic shots and move on. Design We learn from identifying mistakes and misjudgements and then understanding how and why those errors can be avoided next time. It isnt a formulaic approach of applying simple textbook rules of thirds, leading lines or any other compositional straight-jackets. Instead, it is about creating balance, harmony, atmosphere and a connection between the photographer and their subject. Creating that feeling in an image is a craft that examines every aspect of what is included in the frame and asks why? I provide many ways to help you improve your eye for composition and expression. Mentoring/Workshops/Courses/1-2-1 all include image critiques to discuss image design and its intention. Shoot Failing to understand how to use camera settings is a bit like trying to drive a car without a steering wheel; It is impossible to arrive at the desired destination. Steering, in reality, camera settings and, specifically, control of exposure settings are the most important part of photography regarding the mechanics of camera operation. Moving from point and shoot, relying on what the camera does in auto exposure mode to make your own choices about aperture, shutter speed, and ISO are where you first learn the basics of photography. This is essential to your learning and cant be bypassed if you want to create images beyond phone snapshots. My beginners photography course and classes are designed to help you take your first significant step into using your camera with all its power and potential. If evening classes or my locations dont suit you, these essential basics can be taught online via Zoom or on a 1-2-1 basis. Enhance Editing an image is not a sin, crime or deceitful! Photographs, by their very nature of using a camera, lens and settings, are not the reality if you base them on human perception and vision. There is a case for debating how much editing is acceptable, but I think this is down to the photographer making that choice. Dont rely on the camera JPG settings to make those choices. Shoot in RAW format, so you have all ingredients available to fine-tune the image to your taste and vision. Editing your images is part of learning how to improve the decisions you make about camera settings, framing and composing your shots. In fact, I would say with confidence that the process of editing is the fastest route to identifying what you didnt do or see at the moment you took the shot, Learning how to use the editing software of your choice is the first step. It is the how rather than why; then comes the decision of how you want to convey your photographic vocabulary expressing your personal interpretation of your subject. My Beginners Lightroom Course provides all of the basics of how. Through 1-2-1 private lessons, courses and image critiques, we can develop the why further so that you can apply your interpretation to what you want to create. Share Sharing an image is generally about getting some affirmation and feedback about the image you created. Though necessary, it doesnt have to be, nor should that be, a reason for sharing. Sharing can be as simple as showing your friends and family or getting an image printed and framed to give as a gift or hanging on your walls. Those are great outcomes, but when it comes to learning and development objectives, sharing comes more about confirmation that what you created has some merit. Health Warning - social media popularity or competition success/failure should NOT influence your opinion about your images. The key part of sharing, whether public or collaborating with me, is learning and improving all of the process's previous steps. My courses, workshops, mentoring, and 1-2-1 lessons online or face-to-face all provide the opportunity for constructive feedback and image critiques to improve your photography photography-tips, tip-of-the-dayAlan Ranger21 February 2023Alan Ranger Photography LinkedIn0 Pinterest0

@graph.headline: Shooting In Low Light | Long Exposure Photography Guide
@graph.alternativeHeadline: Shooting In Low Light | Long Exposure Photography Guide | Alan Ranger Photography
@graph.description: Shooting In Low Light  Top Tips You might think that photography is limited to the times of day or when we utilise man-made lights. | Long Exposure Photography.
@graph.articleBody: Shooting In Low Light | Long Exposure Photography Guide Shooting In Low Light  My Top Tips You might think that photography is limited to the times of day or when we utilise the man-made lights. Daylight isnt the limit though and there are plenty of ways you can discover the beauty of photography in the darkness of night and poorly lit areas. Here are my top tips to shooting quality images without relying on daylight. Open your aperture The aperture is the opening inside your lens that opens and closes based on the F number you set to control how much is in focus in the picture - with low light you may need to open your aperture to wider hole (lower F number) to balance depth of focus over exposure time. Experiment with shutter speed The exposure time is determined by length of time required to capture enough light to expose the photo correctly - this is a calculation based on the Aperture, Shutter Speed and ISO setting you set. In Aperture Priority mode (A or AV) the camera meters the frame you are shooting and calculate the shutter speed for you based on the aperture you have set. In S or TV mode you set the shutter speed and the camera calculates the aperture for you. You have to decide which is more important and balance the exposure between aperture and shutter speed according to your requirements for depth of focus and length of exposure - You can of course use ISO to decrease the exposure time but at the cost of increased noise/grain in your image. Naturally low light, night images require longer exposures - this can reveal a dramatic image in a way the human eye doesn't see. Both the light and movement in a shot will not be as your eyes witness the scene. To decide on what shutter speed to select, the best way is to keep experimenting, examine the results and then develop from there. We all have our own views on what makes a beautiful image, so as well as taking my advice, go out there and see what works best for you! One thing to remember is to monitor the exposure on your view finder and tweak settings when needed. The beauty of digital photography is that you can see a shot right after youve taken it! Dont like the shots youre creating? Take them again and again until youre happy. Try a higher ISO Even though this is a somewhat complicated way to combat the troubles of low light, tinkering with the ISO settings can help you reach the results youre aiming for. Setting the ISO yourself will give you more control over how your shots look. Even so, it may be better to try adjusting your aperture and shutter speed before meddling with the ISO settings. You could try and combine black and white shots with a higher ISO to give a more vintage feel to your photos; just as beautiful as vibrant and colourful images. I love seeing how photographers portray emotions and stories without relying on colour. In black and white photography you need to only focus on the light you have available and the unique shapes that can be made with various shades of black, grey and white. Now you know how to take stunning photos in any level of light, you can get out there and put your knowledge to the test. If you feel as though you want to look deeper into the potential of low light photography, why not join me on an evening photography workshop in March or April in Kenilworth? I look forward to seeing your skills grow and develop. photography-tipsAlan Ranger3 January 2023long-exposure LinkedIn0 Pinterest0

@graph.description: Another successful LRPS pass from my mentoring programme. Janice Jordan shares her LRPS - RPS Distinctions, the challenges and the resulting successful panel.
@graph.articleBody: Case Study - Janice Jordan - LRPS | RPS Distinctions View fullsize Janice Jordan LRPS Hanging Plan RPS Distinctions Janice has been a regular client at my events for eight years, so I was delighted when she agreed to take the next step up in her photography development and join my RPS Mentoring Course for RPS distinctions. The pandemic threw a spanner in the works for many clients, and although I switched class sessions from my home to online via Zoom, it was clear that many people struggled to get out and produce new images. Thankfully we were free to go out again after several lockdowns and then it became a question of getting existing clients to be remotivated to pick this up again and continue. Some havent continued post-pandemic, which I understand, as life was changed forever with so much disruption and a rebalancing of priorities for everyone. Janice has always been a fun client to have on workshops and events. She is always keen to discover compositions, techniques and thinking patterns with her approach to image-making. She generally gives me a hard time with her banter, and thats also fine, as I am always willing to give twice as much back  You will see from her final panel of images a great variation in technique, subject matter, the skilful use of perspective and exposure settings to place you at the moment, and the feeling of the place or subject. Empathy for the subject is always a vital part of the skills needed to demonstrate a successful panel. The RPS assessors dont always get it right but generally look for photographer input, awareness, communication and technical execution. Well done, Janice, a bit too long getting to this milestone, but I hope you will be motivated now to continue the journey and look to start creating bodies of work for an A panel and your own satisfaction. The assessors also commented on Janices panel for her paper choice for the printing, done by One Vision Imaging Ltd, who supported her with several test prints before the final panel production. Interview with Janice on for rPS distinctions1. Why did you want to gain a distinction with the Royal Photographic Society (RPS)? It seemed the next natural step. Im best motivated by having a project so this was ideal for me. It was also a way for me to understand and focus on areas in which I needed to improve. 2. Why did you choose Alan to mentor you for a distinction and had you worked with Alan before the RPS Distinctions Mentoring Course? I first met Alan at a Get Off Auto workshop in around 2014 and was hooked from the first session. I attended many workshops across a whole range of subjects with Alan together with various day and residential workshops and, therefore, there was never any question that I would choose and trust Alan to mentor me in order to get to the next level. 3. Describe how you found the RPS Distinctions Mentoring Classes. I cant really fault the format of the mentoring classes as they are restricted to a small group of participants which means that Alan is able to give each participant the right amount of time. Being able to listen to Alans critique and advice to the other participants is also really useful. 4. Do you feel you got the right level and input of support from the course? Yes, I found it helpful that Alan gives you some flexibility to work at your own pace within the framework of lessons. There is also the support and understanding from others in the group that is sharing the experience. For me, this extended outside of the workshops with shared trips to locations and events to help us fill the gaps in our portfolios. 5. Did you feel you were already good enough to gain a distinction with the RPS before you started the mentoring course? Personally, I didnt think I was good enough, but Alan suggested it was the next step and I trusted his judgment. The mentoring course was challenging for me, but Alans feedback and critique certainly helped me improve. In hindsight, I learned a great deal from the experience. The mentoring course certainly gave me a focus and has made me think differently about the creative side of photography. 6. What distinction did you apply for and were you successful? I applied for the L and was successful. 7. What was your experience like of the RPS Assessment Day? I attended the assessment day on Zoom as I couldnt make the trip to Bristol. Luckily I was first on, so I didnt have to wait long in my calmly stressed state. I was pleasantly surprised at the positive feedback I had from the assessors, and it has certainly given me more confidence in my ability. 8. Did you seek independent advice, feedback or input from anywhere else before your panel assessment? I booked a 1:1 with an RPS assessor to review my draft panel. This was invaluable as it gave an insight into what the assessors would be looking for. The advice given certainly helped me refine the panel layout and images to bring it up to the required standard 9. Having completed the course and Distinction Assessment, what advice would you like to share with others? Use the checklist provided by Alan, which helps you review the images you have and highlights the gaps you need to fill. Also, having taken part in an assessment day, my advice would be to have your panel critiqued by an RPS assessor before submission to give you the best chance of being successful. 10. What was the hardest part of gaining a distinction with the RPS and why? Staying motivated and also processing images to the required standard. Sometimes having to go back and start processing again. 11. Has working for a distinction helped you progress as a photographer? Yes, it taught me a lot about composition and camera technique. It also helped me improve my processing skills in Lightroom. 12. Any other comments you would like to add? I would never have achieved a distinction without Alans support, patience and perseverance, so thank you. Having watched a live assessment made me realise that his attention to detail and critique is absolutely necessary and gave me the best chance of success. Click on images to see full screen If you are interested in attaining a distinction with the RPS I can support you with my RPS Courses for distinctions RPS Mentoring Course Summary- Produce a panel of images for an RPS Distinctions Qualification  Zoom - Online  Evening Class - 19:00 - 21:00. Six classes, you choose dates, within a twelve-month period to suit  From 395 Having supported many clients through a journey of development and improvement, with their photography, over the past few years, this mentoring course is for those who are already technically competent (or at least are on the path to mastering it) and are able to demonstrate good design and composition in their photography. You are not expected to be a master or even polished to attend. This RPS Distinctions course is to help support you in improving in all three areas of image production:  Technical - The mechanics of it Creativity - The reason for it Output - The editing and publication of it You will be expected to understand and demonstrate or be willing to learn; Good exposure of photographs Good compositional awareness A range of techniques and styles (L) or specific themed body of work (A) Ability to edit images to a "reasonable" standard. Over the course of 12 months, where you will attend six RPS Distinctions classes at intervals suited to you, there will be professional input, feedback and support to help you progress towards either the A or L distinction with the RPS Photography Tuition comes in all shapes and sizes - you may be one of those who prefers practical or theory - you may be someone who can't attend classes in the Midlands or in the evenings. You may live abroad or just have limited time or money. Whatever your constraints remember that I can provide a varied package of photography tuition to suit anyone's needs and budgets. Learning is so much easier and more fun when done with the support of a professional and the friends you will make whilst doing it. @graph.alternativeHeadline: Top 6 Tips for Photographing Fireworks from a Professional | Alan Ranger Photography
@graph.description: Bonfire Night, Christmas and New Year; Read my free top six Tips for photographing fireworks over the celebration periods of the year | Photography News Blog |.
@graph.articleBody: Top 6 Tips for Photographing Fireworks from a Professional Photographing Fireworks Top 6 Tips for Photographing Fireworks Bonfire Night, Christmas and New Year; for the next couple of months fireworks will be far from few as we celebrate on a regular basis this winter. As with any major event, we like to make memories by taking photos that we can reminisce over years to come. However, with fireworks being so fast and short, it can be difficult to take the perfect shot if you don't know what you're doing. So, here are my tips for successful Photographing Fireworks Scout Out the Area Know youre environment. Where will be the best place to take shots from? What angle will be best? Where can you shoot so people don't get in the way? Preparing early is the best way to ensure you get successful shots instead of mediocre ones. It also helps to get there 1-2 hours early to make sure your preferred spot hasn't been taken by the general public or other photographers. Being upwind from where the fireworks are being set off is also advantageous to avoid being smoked out. Use a Tripod Theres nothing worse than thinking you've captured the perfect shot only to find that you were moving too much, making the photo blurry and distorted. By using a tripod you can avoid this disappointment and focus more on where youll be shooting. Having a remote release for your camera can also be useful in keeping your tripod steady during shoots. Timers can be a little trickier as you have to time the shots further in advance. Still, practice makes perfect! Turn Off Your Flash Theres no need for the flash on your camera. If anything, it'll make your photos worse. Set it to manual mode so you can control the aperture and exposure yourself. Don't let the camera decide whats best as most cameras cant handle working in limited light. Take control and make the perfect photos yourself! Size Your Frame Well Remember that when fireworks explode, they spread out in all directions, so you need to anticipate how far they'll spread. Of course, this is trial and error, so don't worry too much if you miss the first few shots, as youre getting used to the spread of the fireworks. Perhaps try both vertical and horizontal arrangements so you can take various shots. Review your shutter speeds Setting your shutter speed to bulb (or b) is advisable as there is no time set for the exposure and you can open and close manually when you feel you've captured enough bursts in one shot. You shouldn't keep the shutter open for too long as you can overexpose your shot, resulting in a blur of light and colour. A lot of photographers suggest is with the bulb or b setting is that you should open the shutter as soon as you're either hear or see the firework shoot into the air and leave it open until the firework begins to fade. Experiment Don't let these rules tie you down. The best part about photography is experimenting and seeing what works best for you. Discovering what works and what doesn't is part of the fun so get out there and test your camera skills! Are you going to any fireworks displays this winter or planning to test yourself? Id love to see the photos you take and I'm willing to answer any questions you might have. My workshop at Kenilworth Fireworks Display is sell out quickly, so don't miss out next time, book yourself for next years workshop today and learn the secrets to getting professional looking firework images. http://www.alanranger.com/photographic-workshops/kenilworth-fireworks-25hrs Have fun this winter and get shooting! photography-tipsAlan Ranger0 Pinterest0
